Includes the Cayman Islands and the southen part of the Bahamas (Exuma, Inagua).

Conventional symbolism for hills, and for drowned lands; signs appear for municipal and ecclesiastical authorities and for the centers of estates ("hato, ó caserio"), keyed to an "Explicacion de las Señales" on sheet 2. The customary track of the galleons from Cartagena to Havana, and thence to Spain, is marked; compass indicator on sheet 2. Soundings given plentifully around the coast.

Title in lower left corner of sheet 1, in an elaborate rococo cartouche of a shell with marine motifs. On the right of this sheet a long note accounts for the sources of this map as an (anonymous) manuscript drawn in Havana in 1770; ditto, manuscripts by Antonio López y Gómez, and Agustín Crame, and one of the Gulf of Mexico by various Spanish pilots. Debts are acknowledged also to Jefferys' printed map in The West India atlas, drawn from a Spanish map taken in Havana in 1762; and from other sources given here; and to Andrés García de Céspedes, Hidrografía, on the correction of the 16th-century Padrón Real so far as the Old Bahama Channel was concerned, by pilots named Acosta.
Mercator's projection. Prime meridian of Tenerife, Canary Is.
Given on a scale of "Leguas Maritimas que se usan en España, Francia, é Inglaterra, de las que entran 20 en un grado," up the left-hand side of sheet 1.
